question.title: Will Glenn Youngkin be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Glenn Youngkin is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Glenn Youngkin, the current Governor of Virginia, has gained some national attention within the Republican Party, but as of the latest information available up to October 2023, he has not announced a candidacy for the 2024 Presidential Election. The primary contenders for the Republican nomination appear to be former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, both of whom have been more prominently featured in national discussions and polls regarding the 2024 election. Additionally, other potential candidates such as former Vice President Mike Pence and former UN Ambassador Nikki Haley have been mentioned more frequently in the context of the presidential race. Youngkin's relative lack of national political experience compared to these figures may also be a factor against his nomination. However, political dynamics can change rapidly, and there is still time for Youngkin to build a stronger national presence if he chooses to run. Overall, while it is not impossible for Youngkin to become the nominee, the probability seems low given the current political landscape and the prominence of other candidates.

question.title: Given Larry Elder is the Republican nominee, will Glenn Youngkin also be the nominee?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Then, is Glenn Youngkin also selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?

Resolution criteria: The question resolves as YES if Glenn Youngkin is indeed selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, despite Larry Elder also being selected. It resolves as NO if Glenn Youngkin is not selected. Note that this scenario is logically inconsistent under typical single-nominee conditions.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The scenario presented in the question is logically inconsistent under typical conditions for the selection of a presidential nominee by the Republican National Convention. Traditionally, a political party selects only one nominee for the presidential election. If Larry Elder is already selected as the nominee, it would be highly unusual and against the norm for Glenn Youngkin to also be selected as a nominee for the same election cycle. The Republican National Convention typically follows a process where delegates vote to select a single candidate who will represent the party in the presidential election. Therefore, the probability of both Larry Elder and Glenn Youngkin being selected as nominees is extremely low, assuming no changes to the conventional process or extraordinary circumstances that would allow for multiple nominees.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of the current date, Joe Biden has been actively campaigning for re-election in the 2024 presidential race. Historically, incumbents who seek re-election generally do not withdraw unless there are significant health issues or political scandals, neither of which are evidently affecting Biden at this time. Additionally, the Democratic Party has shown strong support for his candidacy, and there are no clear indications from Biden or his campaign suggesting he plans to step down. Given the proximity to the resolution date, it is unlikely that Biden will make such an announcement unless there is an unexpected and significant development. Therefore, the probability that Biden will announce he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024, is low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question revolves around the possibility of Donald Trump being removed or blocked from a primary election ballot for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This section addresses the disqualification from holding office for those who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. There have been discussions and legal attempts to apply this clause to Trump due to his alleged involvement in the January 6, 2021, Capitol riot. However, the application of this amendment is legally complex and unprecedented in modern times, especially for a former president.

As of October 2023, there have been legal challenges in various states attempting to invoke Section 3 of the 14th Amendment against Trump. However, these cases are highly contentious and face significant legal and political hurdles. The interpretation of the amendment, the evidentiary standards required, and the political implications make it uncertain whether any state will successfully remove him from the ballot by July 15, 2024.

Additionally, Trump has a substantial legal team and political support, which would likely result in prolonged legal battles and appeals against any such removal. The resolution of these cases by July 15, 2024, is uncertain, and even if a state initially removes him, appeals or political pressure could lead to his reinstatement before the resolution date.

Given these factors, while there is a non-zero possibility of removal, the probability of Trump being officially removed or blocked from a primary election ballot in any state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by the specified date remains relatively low.

question.body:

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

Given these considerations, the probability of him remaining in office through July 2024 is high, barring unforeseen events.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question at hand involves the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which disqualifies individuals from holding office if they have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. For Donald Trump to be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state, a state government or court would have to determine that his actions meet the criteria outlined in this section.

Several factors must be considered:

1. **Legal Precedent and Interpretation**: The use of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment in modern times is relatively untested, especially concerning a former President. Legal scholars and courts may have differing interpretations of what constitutes "insurrection or rebellion" and whether Trump's actions qualify.

2. **Political and Legal Will**: States would need the political and legal motivation to pursue such actions. Given Trump's significant influence within the Republican Party, there may be reluctance from Republican-led states to pursue this course. However, Democratic-led states might be more inclined to explore this option.

3. **Ongoing Legal Challenges**: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been discussions and some legal attempts to apply Section 3 to Trump, but no definitive rulings have been made. Legal proceedings can be lengthy and complex, and any decision would likely be appealed up to higher courts, potentially delaying final outcomes past the resolution date.

4. **Timing and Resolution Date**: The resolution date of July 15, 2024, is critical. Even if a state were to initially remove Trump from the ballot, legal challenges could result in his reinstatement before this date, which would lead to the question resolving as "No."

5. **Public and Political Pressure**: The political climate and public opinion can influence decisions. If there is significant pressure or evidence presented that sways legal or political bodies, it could impact outcomes.

Considering these factors, while there is a possibility that legal action could be taken to remove Trump from a ballot under Section 3, the combination of legal complexity, political dynamics, and the specific resolution criteria make it less likely that such a removal would be upheld as of July 15, 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around the hypothetical scenario where Ted Cruz becomes the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, and whether Donald Trump will be removed from any primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. As of the current date, there have been discussions and legal actions taken by some groups to have Trump disqualified under this amendment due to his alleged involvement in the January 6th Capitol riot. However, for Trump to be removed from a primary ballot under the 14th Amendment, there would need to be a successful legal challenge upheld by the courts in at least one state by July 15, 2024. Considering the complexity and rarity of such legal actions, the political implications, and the time frame involved, it seems unlikely that Trump will be officially removed from any primary ballot under the specified conditions by the given date. Historically, the USA has been a dominant force in the Olympics, often securing a high number of Gold medals. question.body:

The medal table is calculated by taking all the medals won by each participating country and ordering by:

1. Number of Gold Medals
2. (Where 1 is tied) Number of Silver Medals
3. (Where 2 is tied) Number of Bronze Medals

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context provided indicates that there is significant discontent among some House Democrats regarding the early nomination plan for President Biden. A letter has been drafted and is being circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman, suggesting that there is already some level of organization and intention to gather signatures. The fact that the letter has been obtained by POLITICO implies that the issue is gaining public attention, which could increase pressure on lawmakers to take a stance. Additionally, the involvement of "dozens" of House Democrats in organizing a plan to speak out suggests that reaching the threshold of 20 signatures is plausible. However, the exact number of lawmakers willing to publicly oppose the party's plan is uncertain, and political dynamics, such as party loyalty and strategic considerations, could influence the final number of signatures. Given these factors, while there is a reasonable chance that the letter could gain the necessary support, there remains uncertainty about whether it will reach the threshold of 20 signatures.

question.title: Will INC form the government after the next Indian general election in 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the INC has a member sworn in as the next Indian Prime Minister following the next general elections. All other parties will resolve as **No**.

This question will resolve for the next general election occurring after June 1, 2022 (currently expected for May 2024).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Indian National Congress (INC) has historically been one of the major political parties in India, but in recent years, it has faced significant challenges. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), led by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has been the dominant force in Indian politics, winning the 2014 and 2019 general elections with a substantial majority. The BJP's popularity, strong organizational structure, and Modi's leadership have contributed to its electoral successes. The INC has struggled with internal leadership issues, a lack of cohesive strategy, and diminishing influence in several key states. While the INC has attempted to revitalize its image and expand its voter base, it faces stiff competition from the BJP and other regional parties. Moreover, the Indian electorate has shown a preference for stable governance, which the BJP has capitalized on. For the INC to form the government in 2024, it would need to significantly improve its performance compared to the previous two general elections. This would require not only winning a substantial number of seats but also forming alliances with regional parties to secure a majority in the Lok Sabha. Given the current political landscape and the BJP's strong position, the probability of the INC forming the government after the 2024 general elections appears low.

question.title: Will a group of at least 5 named Dem House Members or US Senators pressure Biden to drop out before July 20th?
question.body:
Politico reports:

Two safe-seat members have already publicly urged Biden out. Two of the most endangered Democrats told local news outlets they’ve already written off Biden’s chances to win in November.

Behind the scenes, things are even more frenzied. There are multiple drafts of letters circulating among House Democrats and at least one would call on Biden to end his campaign, according to five people familiar with the efforts.

This market resolves YES if a group of at least five named Democratic Party US House Members/US Senators work together to ask Joe Biden to consider ending his 2024 re-election campaign, or to urge him to do so, before Saturday July 20th (Pacific Time).

This could be by signing a letter like what is reported above, but it could also be in another form such as a group speaking with Biden in person and collectively asking him to drop out.

This market requires that all five individuals be part of the same group message. Five people separately telling reporters they think Biden should drop out is not sufficient for a YES resolution.

Reports of any number of unnamed democrats writing to Biden and asking him to step aside will not satisfy this market's criteria unless at least 5 qualifying names are later made public before this market's end date. In any ambiguous cases where such names are reported but not confirmed beyond a reasonable doubt, this market will err towards resolving NO. 

If these criteria are not met before July 20th, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The question revolves around whether a group of at least five named Democratic US House Members or Senators will collectively urge President Biden to drop out of the 2024 re-election campaign before July 20th. The context provided by Politico indicates some discontent among Democrats regarding Biden's re-election chances. However, the criteria for a YES resolution are quite stringent: it requires a coordinated action by at least five named individuals, not just individual expressions of discontent.

1. **Current Political Climate**: While there is some dissatisfaction with Biden's re-election prospects, it's important to note that the Democratic Party tends to rally around incumbent presidents to maintain party unity. Publicly urging an incumbent president to drop out is a significant political move that could have ramifications for the individuals involved and the party as a whole.

2. **Historical Precedent**: Historically, it is rare for sitting presidents to be pressured to drop out by members of their own party in such a public and coordinated manner. Even when there is dissatisfaction, party members often work behind the scenes rather than making public calls for withdrawal.

3. **Potential Consequences**: Democratic lawmakers may be hesitant to publicly call for Biden to drop out due to potential backlash from the party and voters. Such a move could be seen as divisive and could harm their own political careers.

4. **Current Reports**: The reports indicate that there are drafts of letters and some behind-the-scenes discussions, but no concrete evidence of a coordinated effort involving at least five named individuals. The requirement for all five to be part of the same group message adds another layer of complexity.

5. **Resolution Criteria**: The requirement that all five individuals be part of the same group message is a high bar. It's not enough for them to individually express their views; they must collectively act as a group.

Considering these factors, while there is some level of dissatisfaction, the likelihood of at least five named Democratic lawmakers publicly and collectively urging Biden to drop out before the specified date seems low.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:

- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability of Russia having control over Chasiv Yar by June 1, 2024, several factors need to be considered. First, the current state of the conflict in Ukraine is crucial. As of the latest information available, the war between Russia and Ukraine is ongoing, with varying degrees of territorial control shifting between the two nations. The Institute for the Study of War (ISW) provides regular updates on these movements, and their maps are a reliable source for understanding control dynamics.

Chasiv Yar is a small town in the Donetsk Oblast, which has been a focal point of conflict due to its strategic importance. Historically, control over such territories has oscillated based on military offensives and counteroffensives. The probability of Russia controlling Chasiv Yar by the specified date depends on several factors:

1. Military Strategy and Resources: Russia's ability to maintain or gain control may depend on its military strategy, resources, and the success of ongoing operations in the region.

2. Ukrainian Resistance and Counteroffensives: Ukraine's military capabilities and the effectiveness of their counteroffensives will play a significant role. Western military aid and support to Ukraine could also impact the dynamics.

3. Diplomatic Developments: Any potential peace talks or ceasefire agreements could alter the situation, potentially freezing the current lines of control.

4. Recent Trends: If recent trends show Russia making gains or losing ground in the region, this would impact the likelihood of their control by the resolution date.

Given these considerations, while Russia has shown the capability to make territorial gains, the strong resistance from Ukraine, supported by international allies, makes the situation highly fluid. As of now, without a definitive trend towards Russian control in recent weeks, the probability remains uncertain but slightly leaning towards a status quo or Ukrainian control.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

The domestic projections also suggest a record-breaking performance, with an expected debut of $160 million to $170 million. These projections are based on the popularity of the characters, the success of previous Deadpool films, and the added appeal of Wolverine. Additionally, the film is expected to play in more theaters compared to previous R-rated films, potentially boosting its box office performance. Given these strong projections and the historical success of similar films, it seems highly likely that "Deadpool x Wolverine" will achieve the biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie. The requirement for resolution is that the Hollywood Reporter or an equivalent publication confirms this record, and given the high projections, it is reasonable to expect such confirmation.

2. **Taylor Swift Cameo**: The likelihood of Taylor Swift having a cameo in the movie is independent of its box office performance. Cameos by celebrities in movies, especially in popular franchises like Deadpool, are not uncommon. However, there is no specific information or rumors suggesting that Taylor Swift will appear in this particular movie. Her involvement would likely be a surprise or a marketing tactic, but without concrete evidence or significant rumors, the probability remains speculative.

Considering both aspects, the probability of the movie not having the biggest R-rated opening (which is unlikely) and Taylor Swift making a cameo (which is uncertain), the overall probability for the question resolving YES is low.

question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, President Joe Biden has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. question.title: Will Will Hurd be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Will Hurd is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Will Hurd, a former U.S. Representative from Texas, announced his candidacy for the Republican presidential nomination in 2024. However, as of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, he has not gained significant traction in the Republican primary race. The leading candidates include former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, both of whom have much higher name recognition, political influence, and fundraising capabilities. Historically, the Republican nomination tends to favor candidates with strong national profiles or significant backing from key party figures and donors. Will Hurd, while respected, does not currently have the same level of national prominence or political machinery as the frontrunners. Additionally, the Republican National Convention typically selects candidates who have performed well in primaries and caucuses, and there is no indication that Hurd has the necessary support to achieve this. Given these factors, the probability that Will Hurd will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election is low.

question.title: Conditional on Will Hurd being the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body:

Resolution criteria for the outcome: Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time.

metadata.chain_of_thought:

1. **Will Hurd as the Republican Nominee**: As of the latest information, Will Hurd is not considered a frontrunner for the Republican nomination. The Republican field has several prominent figures, including former President Donald Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, who have higher name recognition and more substantial support within the party. Thus, the probability of Hurd securing the nomination is relatively low.

2. **Biden Dropping Out**: President Biden, as the incumbent, is likely to continue his campaign unless faced with significant health issues or political pressure. Historically, incumbents rarely drop out of the race, and there is no current indication that Biden is considering doing so. Additionally, the scenario of Will Hurd being the nominee does not inherently increase the likelihood of Biden dropping out, as Hurd is not perceived as a uniquely strong or threatening candidate compared to others in the Republican field.

Given these considerations, the combined probability of both events occurring (Hurd becoming the nominee and Biden dropping out) is quite low. Even if we assume a low probability for each event individually, their conjunction is even less likely.

question.title: Will OpenAI publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: OpenAI has been increasingly transparent about the development and safety of their AI models. They have previously engaged in external evaluations and collaborations to ensure the safety and alignment of their technologies. Furthermore, OpenAI has shown a commitment to sharing information with the public through various reports and publications. The trend in the AI industry, particularly among leading organizations like OpenAI, is to emphasize safety and ethical considerations, which often involve external audits and red-teaming exercises. Given these factors, it is reasonable to expect that OpenAI would continue this practice and publish a report by the specified date. However, there are uncertainties related to the timing and specific nature of such publications, as they depend on internal and external processes, and unforeseen delays can occur. Taking these considerations into account, it seems likely that OpenAI will publish such a report by June 30, 2024.

question.title: Will Anthropic publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, Anthropic publishes a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Anthropic is a prominent AI research company known for its focus on AI safety and ethics. The company has expressed a commitment to transparency and responsible AI development. Red-teaming, which involves stress-testing models for vulnerabilities and risks, is a common practice in AI safety to ensure models do not behave unexpectedly or harmfully. Given the increasing scrutiny on AI companies to demonstrate the safety and reliability of their models, it is plausible that Anthropic would engage in external red-teaming efforts and publish the results to align with industry standards and public expectations. Additionally, there is a growing trend in the AI industry towards openness and sharing of safety practices, which further supports the likelihood of such a report being published. However, the decision to publish such a report might also be influenced by strategic considerations, competitive pressures, or the outcomes of the red-teaming process itself. Therefore, while it is likely that Anthropic will publish a report by the specified date, there remains some uncertainty.

question.title: Given Anthropic publishes a report with external red-teaming results by June 30, 2024, will OpenAI do the same?
question.body:
This question explores whether OpenAI will publish a public report with results from an external party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models by June 30, 2024, given that Anthropic does so by that date. 

Resolution criteria for the condition (P): The condition is satisfied if, by June 30, 2024, Anthropic publishes a public report with the results from an external party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

Resolution criteria for the outcome (Q): Resolves YES if, by June 30, 2024, OpenAI publishes a public report with the results from an external party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models. Resolves NO otherwise. If the condition is not met, resolves N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability of OpenAI publishing a report with external red-teaming results by June 30, 2024, assuming Anthropic does so, we must consider several factors. First, OpenAI and Anthropic are both key players in the AI industry, and they are likely to be influenced by each other's actions, particularly in areas related to AI safety and transparency. If Anthropic publishes such a report, it could set a precedent or create pressure for OpenAI to follow suit to maintain its reputation as a leader in AI safety and ethics.

Additionally, OpenAI has shown a commitment to transparency and safety in the past, as evidenced by their publication of safety-related research and their engagement with external audits and collaborations. The AI industry is also under increasing scrutiny from regulators, the public, and other stakeholders, which may incentivize OpenAI to demonstrate their commitment to safety through external evaluations.

However, there are also reasons for caution. OpenAI may have strategic or proprietary reasons for not publishing such a report, or they may have different timelines or approaches to external red-teaming. The decision could also depend on the nature and findings of Anthropic's report and whether OpenAI sees a similar report as beneficial or necessary.

Overall, given OpenAI's track record and the potential influence of Anthropic's actions, there is a reasonable likelihood that OpenAI will publish a similar report, but uncertainty remains due to strategic considerations and the specific context of the situation.

Competitive Pressure: If Anthropic, a competitor, does not publish a report, OpenAI might see an opportunity to differentiate itself by demonstrating a commitment to transparency and safety. Industry Trends: The AI industry is increasingly focused on safety and ethical considerations, with many stakeholders advocating for external audits and transparency. question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of President Biden remaining in office through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, Biden's health and age are significant considerations, as he is the oldest sitting president in U.S. history. However, as of October 2023, there have been no public indications of severe health issues that would necessitate resignation or prevent him from serving. Second, political factors such as impeachment or resignation due to scandal are always possibilities, but there is no current indication of any imminent threat in this regard. Historically, most U.S. presidents complete their terms unless faced with extraordinary circumstances. The political environment, while contentious, does not currently suggest a high likelihood of removal from office. Additionally, the temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not affect the resolution of this question. Considering these factors, while acknowledging the inherent uncertainties, the probability of Biden remaining president through the specified date seems relatively high.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question is about whether Donald Trump will be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024. Section 3 of the 14th Amendment is a Civil War-era provision that disqualifies individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding office. Recently, there have been discussions and legal challenges regarding Trump's eligibility based on this provision, mainly due to his actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot.

However, removing a candidate from the ballot based on this provision is unprecedented and would likely face significant legal challenges. The interpretation and application of Section 3 are complex and would likely require court rulings to enforce. As of now, no state has removed Trump from the ballot for this reason, and any attempt to do so would likely be contested in court, potentially delaying any final decisions beyond the resolution date of this question.

Moreover, the political ramifications of such a move would be significant, and states may be hesitant to set such a precedent without clear legal backing. Given the lack of precedent and the high likelihood of legal and political challenges, the probability of Trump being removed or blocked from the ballot in any state under this provision by July 15, 2024, seems relatively low.

question.title: Given Donald Trump is removed or blocked from a primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will Biden remain President through July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: On July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. This is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements do not suffice for resolution. The question strictly pertains to whether Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the condition is not met.

Then, is it true that Biden will remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET)? This resolves YES if Biden remains President through the end of July 2024. It resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment (making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a NO resolution, as Acting President is different from President under the Constitution.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To address this question, we need to consider the likelihood of two events: Donald Trump being removed or blocked from a primary election ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, and whether Joe Biden will remain President through July 2024.

1. **Trump's Removal Under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment:**
   - Section 3 of the 14th Amendment was originally designed to disqualify individuals who engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States from holding public office.
   - There have been discussions and some legal actions attempting to use this provision to disqualify Trump due to his actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot. However, as of October 2023, no court has definitively ruled to remove him from a ballot under this provision.
   - Legal challenges are complex and could be drawn out, with potential appeals reaching higher courts, including the Supreme Court. The resolution of such cases by July 2024 is uncertain.
   - The political and legal implications of such a move are significant, and courts may be cautious in setting a precedent.

2. **Biden Remaining President through July 2024:**
   - Joe Biden has been serving as President since January 20, 2021. As of October 2023, there are no indications that he plans to resign or that there are any significant health concerns that would suggest he might not complete his term.
   - The question specifies that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not count as Biden ceasing to be President. This means that even if there were a temporary situation where the Vice President becomes Acting President, it would not affect the resolution.
   - Historically, sitting Presidents tend to complete their terms unless there are extraordinary circumstances.

Considering these factors, the probability of Biden remaining President through July 2024 seems high. The removal of Trump from a ballot under the specified conditions does not directly impact Biden's presidency. Therefore, the likelihood of Biden remaining President is primarily dependent on his health and political circumstances, both of which currently suggest stability.

question.title: Conditional on Donald Trump not being removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, will Biden remain President through the end of July 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Donald Trump has not been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment as of July 15, 2024. This is confirmed by the lack of official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports indicating such a removal or block.

Then is it true that Biden will remain US President through the end of July 2024 (ET)? This resolves YES if Biden remains President through that time, and NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then. A temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not affect this resolution.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question is asking about the likelihood that Joe Biden remains President of the United States through the end of July 2024, given that Donald Trump is not removed or blocked from the primary election ballot in any U.S. state under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The condition regarding Trump does not directly affect Biden's status as President. Therefore, the main factors to consider are Biden's health, any potential political developments, and historical precedents.

1. **Health and Age**: Joe Biden, born in 1942, is the oldest president in U.S. history. While age and health are potential concerns, there have been no major public health issues reported that would suggest he is unlikely to complete his term through July 2024.

2. **Political Stability**: There are no significant political movements or legal challenges currently known that could lead to Biden resigning or being removed from office. The Democratic Party appears unified in support of his presidency, and there is no indication of any impeachment proceedings.

3. **Historical Precedent**: Historically, most U.S. presidents complete their terms unless there are extraordinary circumstances such as major health issues or political scandals that lead to resignation or removal. None of these conditions seem to apply to Biden at this time.

4. **Temporary Transfer of Power**: The prompt specifies that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th Amendment does not affect the resolution. This means that even if Biden temporarily transfers power to the Vice President, it would not impact the outcome of this question.

Given these considerations, the probability that Biden remains President through the end of July 2024 is high, barring unforeseen circumstances.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to FiveThirtyEight's national polling average, we need to consider several factors:

1. **Current Polling Trends**: As of early July 2024, if Trump is already leading by a certain margin, understanding how stable that lead is will be crucial. If Trump has consistently been leading by margins around 2 to 3 points, this could suggest a higher probability of the lead being in that range on July 15.

2. **Historical Polling Volatility**: National polls can fluctuate significantly over time due to various factors such as major political events, debates, or new information about the candidates. If the historical data shows that Trump's lead has been volatile, this could decrease the probability of the lead being within a narrow band of 2 to 3 points.

3. **Political Events**: Any significant events or developments in the political landscape leading up to July 15, 2024, could influence voter preferences. This includes economic reports, foreign policy issues, or major campaign announcements.

4. **Polling Methodology**: The methodologies used by pollsters and how they aggregate data could also impact the reported lead. FiveThirtyEight's model incorporates a range of polls and adjusts for factors like pollster quality and historical accuracy.

5. **Margin of Error**: Polls have a margin of error, which means the reported lead could vary slightly. This inherent uncertainty must be considered when predicting a specific range.

Given these factors, while it's possible for the lead to fall within the 2 to 3 point range, the combination of potential volatility and external influences makes it less certain. If current trends show Trump consistently leading within or near this range, the probability increases. However, without exact current polling data, a moderate probability seems reasonable.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Joe Biden is the incumbent President and has already announced his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential race. Historically, sitting presidents who seek re-election typically stay in the race unless there are significant health issues, political scandals, or other extraordinary circumstances that force them to withdraw. As of now, there have been no major indications of such issues affecting Biden's candidacy. Additionally, withdrawing from the race could create significant challenges for the Democratic Party, as they would need to quickly establish a new frontrunner and rally support around a new candidate. Given these factors, it is unlikely that Biden will announce he will not accept the nomination before the specified date. Therefore, the probability of a YES resolution is relatively low.

question.title: If Joe Biden announces he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden announces before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not seek and will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in the 2024 cycle. The announcement must be definitive, public, official, unambiguous, and conclusive, leaving no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the nomination.

Then, is it true that Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3? This is based on the 538 national polling average for the 2024 presidential election as reported on the chart for July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the probability of Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, several factors need to be considered:

1. **Impact of Biden's Withdrawal**: If Joe Biden announces he will not seek the Democratic nomination, this would be a significant political event. Such an announcement could lead to a period of uncertainty and reorganization within the Democratic Party as they select a new candidate. This could temporarily affect polling numbers, potentially benefiting Trump.

2. **Polling Volatility**: Polls can be volatile, especially in the wake of major political announcements. While Biden's withdrawal might initially boost Trump's polling numbers, the extent of this boost is uncertain. The range specified (greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3) is quite narrow, making it more challenging to predict with high confidence.

3. **Historical Context and Trends**: Historically, major announcements can lead to short-term shifts in polling, but the effect can diminish as the political landscape stabilizes. Additionally, the Democratic Party's response and the emergence of a strong candidate could counterbalance any initial advantage Trump might gain.

4. **Current Political Climate**: As of the last available data, the political climate is highly polarized, and both major parties have strong bases. Any lead Trump might gain could be mitigated by Democratic efforts to rally around a new candidate.

5. **538's Methodology**: 538's national polling average aggregates multiple polls and applies a model to account for biases and errors, which can provide a more stable estimate than individual polls. This could dampen the immediate impact of Biden's announcement.

Given these considerations, while it is plausible that Trump's lead could fall within the specified range due to the initial shock of Biden's announcement, the narrowness of the range and the potential for Democratic countermeasures make it uncertain.

question.title: If Joe Biden does not announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination, will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Joe Biden does not announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President. This means there is no definitive, public, official announcement from Biden or his campaign indicating that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination for another term as President in the 2024 cycle.

Given this scenario, will Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average? This question will resolve based on the value reported on 538's national polling average chart for the date of July 15, 2024, accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024. A positive value indicates a Trump lead, while a negative value indicates a Biden lead. For example, a value of 2.4 means Trump is 2.4 points ahead of Biden.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average, we need to consider several factors:

1. **Current Polling Trends**: As of the latest data (October 2023), national polling averages have shown fluctuating leads for both Trump and Biden. Historically, polling averages can vary significantly over time due to political events, economic conditions, and campaign strategies.

2. **Political Climate**: The political environment in 2024 will play a crucial role. Factors such as the state of the economy, major legislative achievements or failures, and international events can influence public opinion. Additionally, any significant controversies or scandals involving either candidate could shift polling numbers.

3. **Historical Precedents**: In previous election cycles, polling leads within a 1-point range are not uncommon close to the election date. However, maintaining a lead precisely between 2 and 3 points over a specific period is statistically less likely, given the natural variability in polling data.

4. **538's Methodology**: 538 uses a sophisticated model that aggregates and weights various polls to provide a more stable average. This model accounts for potential biases and methodological differences among polls, which should provide a reliable snapshot of public opinion.

5. **Biden's Decision**: The scenario assumes Biden does not announce he won't accept the nomination. This implies Biden remains a viable candidate, which could stabilize or improve his polling numbers if his campaign performs effectively.

Considering these factors, while it's possible for Trump to have a lead in the specified range, the precise condition of having a lead greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 is relatively narrow. Given the typical volatility in polling data and the range of potential influencing factors, the probability of this specific outcome is moderate.

question.title: Will Liz Cheney be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Liz Cheney is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought:

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Joe Biden is the incumbent President of the United States and has expressed his intention to run for re-election in the 2024 presidential cycle. Historically, sitting presidents who are eligible for re-election often seek a second term, barring significant personal, political, or health issues. Biden has announced his candidacy for the 2024 election, which suggests he is committed to running. Furthermore, as of the latest updates, there have been no significant indications or rumors suggesting that Biden plans to withdraw from the race or decline the nomination. The Democratic Party has not shown signs of preparing for an alternative candidate, which would likely be evident if there were substantial doubts about Biden's candidacy. Given these factors, the probability that Joe Biden will announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination is relatively low.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: To estimate the probability that FiveThirtyEight (538) will project Joe Biden as the favorite over Donald Trump on July 19, 2024, several factors need to be considered. First, historical data from previous election cycles can provide insights into how 538's models have predicted outcomes in the past. In the 2020 election, for example, 538 consistently showed Biden as the favorite over Trump, reflecting polling data and other indicators.

Currently, it is essential to consider the political landscape, including Biden's approval ratings, the state of the economy, major national or international events, and Trump's legal and political challenges. As of my last update, Biden's approval ratings have been relatively stable, and he has been leading Trump in most national polls. Additionally, Trump's legal issues and controversial statements might impact his favorability and perceived electability.

538's methodology incorporates polling data, economic indicators, and other variables, which tend to favor incumbents or candidates with stable polling advantages. If Biden maintains or increases his lead in national and swing state polls, it is likely that 538 will project him as the favorite.

However, it is important to note that the election is still several months away, and the political environment can change rapidly. Any significant shifts in public opinion, economic conditions, or unforeseen events could alter the forecast.

Considering these factors, while there is uncertainty, it seems more likely than not that Biden will be projected as the favorite on July 19, 2024, given current trends and historical precedents.

This market resolves NO if/when Kamala Harris announces anyone else being her running mate.

comment if you have any questions or news 💙

question.title: Will Greece qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Greece participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Greece does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought:

1. **Historical Performance**: Greece has a relatively strong track record in Eurovision, having qualified for the Grand Final numerous times in the past. They have a history of strong performances and tend to receive support from both the jury and the public vote.

2. **Recent Trends**: In recent years, Greece's performance has been somewhat inconsistent. For instance, they have failed to qualify in some years, but have also had strong showings in others. This indicates that while they have potential, their qualification is not guaranteed.

3. **Song and Performance**: The specific song and performance Greece will present in 2024 will significantly impact their chances. If they have a standout entry that resonates with both juries and the public, their chances of qualifying increase. However, as of now, we do not have information on their entry.

4. **Competition**: The strength of the competition in the semi-final Greece is placed in will also affect their chances. If they are in a semi-final with many strong entries, it might be more challenging to qualify.

5. **Voting Patterns**: Voting patterns, including diaspora voting and geopolitical influences, can also play a role. Greece often receives points from countries with large Greek communities or cultural ties.

Given these considerations, while Greece has a reasonable chance of qualifying, it is not a certainty. The lack of current information on their entry and the competition they will face adds uncertainty to the forecast.

This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Joe Biden has indicated his intention to run for re-election in 2024. Historically, incumbent presidents who seek re-election typically do not withdraw from the race unless there are significant health issues or political crises. Given that Biden has already announced his candidacy and there have been no major indications or rumors suggesting he might withdraw, it seems unlikely that he would announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024. Additionally, the Democratic Party would need significant time to prepare an alternative candidate, which would make a sudden withdrawal less feasible. While Biden's age and health are factors that could influence such a decision, there has been no substantial evidence or reports indicating a change in his plans as of now.

question.title: Will Kamala Harris be the Democratic VP?
question.body: If Kamala Harris is nominated as the Democratic VP, this market will resolve to yes. If someone else is selected as VP, this market will resolve to no. If the VP is changed for any reason after the initial nomination, that will not change the resolution of this market. The market can resolve immediately after the nomination.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Kamala Harris is currently the Vice President of the United States under President Joe Biden. Traditionally, incumbent vice presidents are often re-nominated for a second term if the sitting president is running for re-election and there are no significant political or personal issues that would lead to a change in the ticket. As of the last data update in October 2023, there have been no major controversies or public statements suggesting that Kamala Harris would not be re-nominated as the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate. Additionally, changing a vice-presidential candidate is a significant decision that could have electoral implications, and such changes are relatively rare unless there are compelling reasons. Given these considerations, it is likely that Kamala Harris will be re-nominated as the Democratic VP for the 2024 election.

question.title: Given Kamala Harris is not the Democratic VP, will Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President before July 15, 2024?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Kamala Harris is not nominated as the Democratic VP. This means that if she is not selected as VP, the condition is met, and if she is selected, it is not. The condition is determined immediately after the nomination.

Then, the question is: Will Joe Biden announce before 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing that he will not accept the Democratic nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, if Kamala Harris is not the Democratic VP, it suggests a significant shift in the Democratic Party's strategy or internal dynamics. question.title: Will Latvia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Latvia does not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To estimate the probability of Latvia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. **Historical Performance**: Latvia has had mixed results in Eurovision over the years. They have won once, in 2002, but their qualification record in recent years has been inconsistent. It would be useful to look at their performance in the last few contests to gauge any trends. 2. **Current Trends**: The popularity and style of the song Latvia selects can significantly impact their chances. If the song aligns well with current musical trends and has broad appeal, it can increase their chances of qualifying. 3. **Competition**: The number and quality of other participating countries in the semi-final can affect Latvia's chances. If they face strong competitors, it might be harder to qualify. 4. **Voting Patterns**: Eurovision voting can be influenced by geopolitical factors and diaspora voting. Latvia's relationships with other countries and the presence of Latvian communities in other voting countries can play a role. 5. **Changes in Rules**: Any changes in the Eurovision voting system or qualification rules for 2024 could impact Latvia's chances. Given these considerations, while Latvia has the potential to qualify, their inconsistent track record and the competitive nature of Eurovision suggest a moderate probability of qualification.

question.title: Conditional on Australia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, will Latvia also qualify?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Australia participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Then, will Latvia participate in a Semi-final and be officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final? 

Resolution criteria:
- Condition (P): Resolves as **Yes** if Australia is announced as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Resolves as **No** otherwise.
- Outcome (Q): Resolves as **Yes** if Latvia is announced as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. Resolves as **No** otherwise.
- If the condition is not met, resolves as N/A.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of Latvia qualifying for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, conditional on Australia qualifying, we need to consider several factors. Firstly, the qualification of one country (Australia) does not directly influence the qualification of another (Latvia) as each country's qualification is based on its performance, public votes, and jury votes. However, analyzing historical data and trends can provide some insights.

Australia has consistently performed well in Eurovision since its debut, often qualifying for the Grand Final. Latvia, on the other hand, has had a mixed track record, with some years of strong performances and others where they failed to qualify. The qualification depends on the quality of the song, stage performance, and competition from other countries in the same semi-final.

The conditional aspect of the question implies that if Australia qualifies, it might be indicative of a favorable semi-final environment or voting pattern that could also benefit Latvia. However, this is speculative and not strongly supported by historical patterns. Each country's qualification is largely independent, and Latvia's chances are primarily determined by its own entry's appeal and performance.

Considering Latvia's historical performance and the independent nature of the qualification process, the probability of Latvia qualifying, even if Australia does, remains moderate but not particularly high.

question.title: Given Australia fails to qualify for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final, will Latvia qualify?
question.body:
Suppose the following is true: Australia does not qualify for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. This means that Australia participates in a Semi-final and is not officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. 

Then, considering this, will Latvia qualify for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final? This resolves as **Yes** if Latvia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the EBU as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If Latvia does not qualify, it resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The qualification of Latvia for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final depends on several factors, including the quality of their entry, the competition they face in their semi-final, and the voting patterns of the Eurovision audience and juries. The fact that Australia fails to qualify does not directly influence Latvia's chances, as each country's qualification is determined independently based on their performance and votes received. However, it could indirectly affect Latvia's chances if Australia's non-qualification changes the dynamics of the semi-final, such as altering the distribution of points among other competing countries. Historically, Latvia's success in qualifying for the Grand Final has been mixed, with some years seeing strong entries and others not making it through. Without specific information about Latvia's entry for 2024 or the competition in their semi-final, it's challenging to make a precise prediction. However, given the independent nature of the qualification process, Latvia's chances should be considered based on their own merits rather than Australia's outcome.

question.title: Kamala president by Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

The primary resolution source for this market will be official information from the US government, however a consensus of credible reporting will also be used.

Resolver

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Kamala Harris being formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States before July 26, 2024, we need to consider several factors. Firstly, the current President, Joe Biden, would need to be unable to perform his duties for Kamala Harris to be designated as Acting President under the 25th Amendment. This could occur due to health issues, resignation, or other unforeseen circumstances. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there were no significant indicators suggesting that President Biden is likely to leave office or become incapacitated imminently. Additionally, such transitions of power are relatively rare and typically occur under extraordinary circumstances. Considering these factors, while it is not impossible for Kamala Harris to become President or Acting President by the given date, it is relatively unlikely based on the current information and historical precedents.

question.title: Will Biden remain President through end of July 2024?
question.body:
Resolves YES if Biden remains US President through the end of July 2024 (ET); resolves NO if he resigns, dies, or otherwise ceases to be President before then.

Temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendement (i.e. making his VP the Acting President) does not cause a YES resolution. (Acting President is different from President under the Constitution)

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the likelihood of President Biden remaining in office through the end of July 2024, we need to consider several factors including his health, political stability, and historical precedents. Additionally, there are no current indications of political maneuvers or scandals that might lead to his resignation or removal from office. Given these considerations, it is reasonable to assume that he will likely remain in office through the specified date.

Resolution criteria for the outcome: This market will resolve to "Yes" if Vice President Kamala Harris is formally designated as President or Acting President of the United States at any point before July 26, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No". Given the resolution criteria, this would typically occur if President Biden temporarily transferred power to her under the 25th Amendment or if he were to resign, become incapacitated, or pass away. However, the scenario explicitly states that a temporary transfer of power under the 25th amendment does not cause a YES resolution, meaning Harris would need to be formally designated as President, not just Acting President temporarily.

As of the current date, July 2024, there is no significant public indication of President Biden planning to resign or being incapacitated. Historically, temporary transfers of power (e.g., for medical procedures) have been brief and do not result in a formal designation of the Vice President as President.
